@JustinFrenchBr1 @Parrog3 @IvelRev @AffinityWater @EnvAgency ok but it‚Äôs a hugely expensive option compared to aquifers, which is why they are used. The ideal solution is a ‚Äònational grid for water‚Äô to pipe from water-rich north and west to water-poor S and E. But water is really expensive to move as it‚Äôs so heavy. Start by using less.

@picturespete @Parrog3 @IvelRev @AffinityWater @EnvAgency I know - I have a degree in geography from Cambridge thanks. Portsmouth Water Co are proposing a new reservoir by Havant that‚Äôs on chalk, presumably to be clay lined, on a site not in a valley.

@JustinFrenchBr1 @Parrog3 @IvelRev @AffinityWater @EnvAgency New housing has lower water demand: new build regs call for 2 litre flush loos and water saving taps. Older loos flush 10 litres and folks love a water-hungry power shower (uses more than a bath). My shower is 8L/ minute, and new loos to reduce useage.

@JustinFrenchBr1 @Parrog3 @IvelRev @AffinityWater @EnvAgency The aquifer *is* a reservoir - it‚Äôs chalk rock full of holes that fill up in the winter. A reservoir needs a valley with a waterproof bottom - not many of those in chalk-rich Hertfordshire.

@picturespete @Parrog3 @IvelRev @AffinityWater @EnvAgency That‚Äôs weird, surely if there was winter-fed storage such as a reservoir then the abstraction could be reduced in summer and the river flow returned? And demand met. Or say no new housing (hence new demand) till other sources found.
